quoteFirst: It was the dry season of the year, and the air was wonderfully bright and clear.  The atmosphere being in a state of equilibrium (so the doctor told us), was ready to obey even the slightest impulse, and to rush towards any spot where rarefaction was taking place.  Thus, at
quoteLast: ing, as the rays of the sun gain power and shed their influence over the earth, the air from the sea begins to move towards it.  As rarefaction increases, so does the strength of the wind, till by three or four in the afternoon it rushes in with great force, creating a considerable sea, and if a vessel is not well moored, driving her before it.
title:
A Voyage round the World
A book for boys
author: Kingston, William Henry Giles, 1814-1880

quoteTime: about ten o'clock in the morn
quoteLast: ing, and the grounds were almost entirely deserted.
title: The Northern Light
author: Werner, E., 1838-1918; Lowrey, D. M., Mrs. [Translator]

quoteFirst: During these months in the northern parts of the colony and on the coast a N.E. sea breeze sets in daily
quoteLast: ing, and dying away at sunset is succeeded by a westerly or land wind. The yachtsman may generally reckon on these winds; but if the land wind should not set in towards evening the sea breeze may increase to a gale, when he can remain safe at his anchorage till it has blown itself out--a proceeding which generally occupies not more than twenty-four hours.
title: Yachting, Vol. 2
author: Pritchett, R. T. (Robert Taylor), 1828-1907; Blake, G. L.; Dufferin and Ava, Frederick Temple Blackwood, Marquis of, 1826-1902; McFerran, James; Middleton, T. B.

quoteLast: ing, the servants of don Antonio de Carrera put the horses to the berlin, and a few minutes after the old gentleman came forth.
title: The Rebel Chief: A Tale of Guerilla Life
author: Aimard, Gustave, 1818-1883; Wraxall, Lascelles, Sir, 1828-1865 [Translator]

quoteFirst: "Not much. She'll melt on the lower slopes to-day, but the peak'll not begin cataracting snowslides till to-morrow morning,
quoteLast: Day after you might make it."
title:
Boy Scouts in Glacier Park
The Adventures of Two Young Easterners in the Heart of the High Rockies

Made in H. M. Bark "Endeavour", 1768-71

quoteLast: ing of the 23rd we arrived at the _Dramstone_ which is hailed with pleasure by the boats’ crews as marking the termination of the laborious ascent of Hill River. We complied with the custom from whence it derives its name and soon after landing upon Sail Island prepared breakfast.
title: The Journey to the Polar Sea
author: Franklin, John, 1786-1847; Scott, Robert Falcon, 1868-1912 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: Word was sent for the Upgang lifeboat, but before this arrived it was clear the “_Rohilla_” was breaking up.
quoteLast: an unusually large wave swept the wreck and when the foam had cleared away it was seen that the stern had turned turtle, and there was no trace of a number of men who, a few minutes before, had been clinging to that portion of the ship.
title: Craven's Part in the Great War
author: Clayton, John T.; Brayshaw, Thomas, 1856-1931 [Contributor]

quoteFirst: _Thursday, June 2._--Battle of Coal Harbor. We arrived at Coal Harbor
quoteTime: about ten o'clock in the morn
quoteLast: ing. Fighting was still going on. The rebels had attacked the Sixth and Eighteenth corps about two o'clock in the morning, but were repulsed losing five hundred and twenty prisoners, who passed by our battery. We were not in action to-day, but yet exposed to the enemy's artillery fire.
title: Diary of Battery A, First Regiment Rhode Island Light Artillery
author: Reichardt, Theodore

quoteLast: , was said to be that which sunk the Titanic."
title: Sinking of the Titanic and Great Sea Disasters
